title: Londoners 'pay out £18m a year on cash machine fees'
text:
Krispy Kreme UK is getting a more ‘English-friendly’ name 
Londoners spend more than £18m on cash-machine fees every year with low-income earners and the elderly the hardest hit, it has been claimed. 
Free-to-use ATMs should be rolled out at Tube stations and public buildings across the capital to improve access to cash following a wave of bank closures, according to Tories at City Hall. 
The group also calls on Mayor Sadiq Khan to make free cash machines a planning requirement for major new developments under his city-wide London Plan, and classify ATMs as “social infrastructure” in the same vein as schools and GP surgeries. 
The authors estimate Londoners spent more than £18m withdrawing cash from one of the capital’s 1,649 fee-paying machines last year, rather than using one of the nearly 7,000 free ATMs. 
On average paid-for machines charge £1.75, although charges can be up to £10 according to the report. 
GLA member Shaun Bailey said: “Contactless and online payment technology may be the future, but there are still many Londoners who rely on cash to get by. Read more Jailed: 'Career criminals' who blew up ATMs at London train stations 
“It is expensive to be poor - fee-charging machines should be a convenience not a daily requirement. Lack of access disproportionately affects low-income groups, the disabled, and the elderly. 
“The Mayor needs to ensure new developments have access to free cash, and encourage public buildings to include free cash machines.” 
There are already approximately 120 free-to-use cash machines at more than 60 stations on the Tube network, according to figures provided by the Mayor’s office. Transport for London are said to be working to identify new locations for free ATMs. 
Despite the number of free cash machines across the country nearly doubling since 2007, there were 84 million withdrawals from fee-paying machines last year, out of a total 2.8 billion cash withdrawals. 
This year is the 50th anniversary of London’s first automatic teller machine, which was installed at the Enfield branch of Barclays in June 1967. Major banks prepare to shift operations away from London after Brexit 
However, technological shifts have signalled an exodus of bank branches from the high street, with another 22 slated to close in London by the end of the year, according to This Is Money. 
Mr Bailey said: “With bank branches closing and fee-charging machines becoming the norm it is no surprise Londoners are spending £18million on cash withdrawals.” 
A spokesman from Sadiq Khan’s office said City Hall would consider encouraging public buildings to install ATMs, but said planning regulations could not dictate they must be free to use. 
He added: “While Sadiq acknowledges that the availability of free cash points is important, he also recognises that issues of financial inclusion run far deeper and that some individuals need more help to manage their own finances competently. 
“In addition, he is aware that some Londoners still do not have bank accounts, the ability to save and do not insure their homes and belongings against the risk of fire or theft. Combined, these are significant symptoms and causes of social inequality and need to be tackled strategically.” More about:
